explanations.A: I think you've subtracted 1 from each part of the ratio. Remember that ratios have to have a multiplicative relationship, so you can only multiply or divide both by the same value.
explanations.B: It looks like you've subtracted 2 from the number of parts on the right. Remember that the relationship in a ratio must be multiplicative, so you must multiply or divide the right in the same way you deal with the left.
explanations.C: To find 1 part, the left side has been divided by 2. We have to do the same on the right hand side, 7รท2=3.5, so the ratio becomes 1 : 3.5.
explanations.D: It looks like you've done the opposite to each side. When rewriting ratios, you must multiply both sides by the same value, or divide both sides by the same value.

explanations.A: To write this ratio in the form n:1 we need to divide our 7 on the right hand side by 7 to get 1. This means we need to do the same to the left hand side of our ratio, 2 รท 7 = 2/7, giving us 2/7 : 1
explanations.B: Not quite! I think you have subtracted 6 from both sides of the ratio here, however this does not keep our ratios equivalent, which is what we are looking for. What operation should we be doing instead of subtraction?
explanations.C: Not Quite! I think you have divided both parts of the ratio by 2 and then swapped the order around, which we cannot do while keeping them equivalent. Think which way round the target ratio is written compared to the one given in the question, and therefore what we need to divide by.
explanations.D: Have another think! When writing rations in the form n:1 our 'n' does not have to be an integer value.
